Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI: Integrated seismic, geodynamic, and mineral physics studies of multi-scale structures in the lowermost mantle
Award.AbstractNarration: The behavior of materials in the deep Earth constrains the flows that drive plate tectonics. Voluminous eruptions driven by deep mantle sources are thought to have caused global environmental changes. At the core-mantle boundary (CMB) – about 3000 km below the Earth’s surface - dramatic compositional and thermal changes occur. These changes exert a primary influence on the cooling of the planet. They also influence the core dynamics (hence Earth’s magnetic field) and impact mantle thermal convection. Yet, understanding the dynamics of the deep Earth is not trivial. Indeed, multidisciplinary efforts and state-of-the art techniques are required to tackle the complexity of the Earth system. Here, the researchers investigate enigmatic features observed at the core-mantle boundary. To unveil their origin, the team combine expertise in seismology, geodynamics, and experimental mineral physics. The researchers carry out experiments at the extreme pressures prevailing in the mantle. They measure the properties of deep Earth materials using powerful x rays and infrared light at national synchrotron facilities. Taking advantage of recent advances in computational facilities, they simulate the interaction of crustal materials with lower-mantle materials made of multi-scale structures. These materials are brought together by tectonic forces through Earth’s complex history. Outputs of the models are compared with seismic observations, hence gradually unveiling the dynamics of the deep Earth. The project provides support for graduate students at the California Institute of Technology. It also fosters international collaboration with Australia and the UK. <br/><br/>Seismologists have revealed that the mantle side of the CMB is extraordinarily heterogeneous, with km-scale fine structure that could harbor distinct chemical reservoirs. Thermal and chemical heterogeneity, solid-solid phase transitions, elastic anisotropy, variable viscosity, and melting are probably all required to explain the observed complexity. With expertise in seismology, geodynamics and experimental mineral physics, the team connects the atomic scale (thermoelastic properties of deep Earth phases) to the tectonic scale (seismically observed structures and their dynamics) and link all processes to the temporal dimension (reconstruction of tectonic plate history). The researchers conduct a systematic study of the Pacific large low seismic velocity province (LLSVP) and proximal surroundings such as ultralow velocity zones (ULVZs). They use whole seismograms compared against synthetics generated from enhanced tomographic models and thermo-chemical convection models. The models integrate plate tectonic reconstructions constrained by observations and account for materials’ physical properties, including elastic tensors. The experiments assess the sources of the seismic signatures of candidate deep hydrous phases in subducted slab. They include: (1) shear wave speed measurements using inelastic x-ray scattering techniques; and (2) thermal equation of state and stability constraints using x-ray diffraction and synchrotron infrared spectroscopy at lower mantle conditions. The study addresses fundamental questions, such as: can the presence of subducted slabs deform LLSVPs into seismically resolvable 3D shapes (with distinctive anisotropy) and affects D" topography and chemically–distinct structures near the edges of LLSVPs? Are all ULVZs created equally? If hydrous phases can be transported into the lowermost mantle, are they seismically detectable and can they contribute to the stability of a thermo-chemical pile?<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The behavior of materials in the deep Earth constrains the flows that drive plate tectonics. Voluminous volcanic eruptions driven by deep mantle sources are thought to have caused global environmental changes. At the core-mantle boundary -  about 3000 km below the Earth's surface - dramatic compositional and thermal changes occur, influencing the cooling of the planet and core dynamics (hence Earth's magnetic field). Indeed, multidisciplinary efforts and state-of-the art techniques are required to tackle the complex Earth system. With our individual expertise in seismology (Zhan), geodynamics (Gurnis), and experimental mineral physics (Jackson), we have connected the atomic scale to the tectonic scale, while linking processes to the temporal dimension through reconstruction of tectonic plate history. The fundamental questions we have addressed include: How do subducted slabs interact and affect chemically-distinct structures near the edges of Large Low Seismic Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs)? If hydrous phases can be transported into the lower mantle, are they seismically detectable, and if so, at what length scale? Is iron-rich (Mg,Fe)O a source of observable seismic anisotropy in ultralow velocity zones, developed by mantle flow near paleo-slabs?

Beyond scientific findings, the principal goals and impacts of this effort have been the cross-training of young scientists in a multidisciplinary collaborative framework (7 graduate students - including 3 Caltech PhD Dissertations, 5 postdoctoral scholars, and 3 undergraduate/high-school students, half of whom are women). The students, postdocs, and PIs published at least 17 papers in peer-reviewed literature and presented roughly 25 abstracts at scientific conferences and workshops, with highlights summarized here.

Slabs, scattering, and "water" in the mantle:

We applied our inter-source interferometry technique to probe small-scale intra-slab heterogeneity in the mantle transition zone beneath the Japan Sea to understand the chemistry of slab cores by analyzing the scattering content of seismograms. The observed weakening of scattering strength reveals that the dehydration process of the slab core must be complete by 410 km and could possibly lead to (re-)hydration of the slab crust (Shen et al. 2021), a process that could resume the visibility of seismic scatterers at the base of the transition zone. A systematic analysis of the origin of short-wavelength (<10 km) scatterers at 660 km depth, using synthetic seismograms at high frequencies computed on high resolution subduction and long term mixing models coupled with thermodynamics, shows that the origin of the short-wavelength scatters are neither likely from the complex phase transition in the subduction zone, nor from long-term mechanical mixing in the mantle (the traditional model for the origin of seismic scatters in the mantle). Instead, the origin might be intrinsic heterogeneities inside the subducted oceanic lithosphere (Mao et al. 2022), possibly leading to dense oxyhydroxide phase-formation.

The link between water activity in the lower mantle and the spin crossover of ferric iron in dense oxyhydroxide δ-(Al, Fe3+)OOH has been demonstrated, suggesting increased stability of dense oxyhydroxides throughout most of the lower mantle (Buchen et al. 2021; Buchen et al. 2023, under review). We further show that bulk sound speed and shear wave speed anomalies observed at the boundaries of LLSVPs can be produced by 7-12 vol.% δ-(Al,Fe3+)OOH, suggesting that phases in the (Al,Fe3+)OOH-MgSiO2(OH)2 system may also exhibit these properties (Ohira et al. 2021; Strozewski et al. 2023). Accumulation of dense hydrous phases therefore provides a plausible explanation for observed seismic anomalies near LLSVPs.

Underneath the Pacific Plate:

The Large Low Seismic Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs), one of the most significant features above the core-mantle boundary (CMB), are critical for understanding the nature of mantle convection and the evolution of Earth's interior but remain enigmatic. Seismic waveform modeling shows sharp, steep, and tilting boundaries of the Pacific LLSVP and the eastern side of the African LLSVP. We have investigated the tilting angle of LLSVPs' boundary (θ) by running a series of computational models with variable, but high bulk modulus (K) and high density (ρ) in the presence of paleo-slabs in the lower mantle. The outward tilting phenomenon is directly related to the density contrast within the pile as well as between the pile and the slab. Maximum tilting angle is generally linearly decreasing with increasing δρ. Large δK could increase chemical pile stability.

At the mantle base and underneath present day Hawaiʻi, seismic waves sampling the northeastern edge of the Pacific LLSVP show strong waveform complexity and rapid changes in differential time. We integrate constraints from seismic observations, mineral physics, and geodynamic simulations to provide best-fit phase assemblages that strongly support a solid-state ultralow velocity zone (ULVZ) interpretation featuring iron-rich (Mg,Fe)O magnesiowuestite (Lai et al. 2022), where ULVZs could exhibit seismic anisotropy (Jackson and Thomas 2021). Using a dual-technique approach to constrain the melting curve of FeO at CMB conditions, we find that FeO remains a solid at current CMB temperatures, providing strong evidence for magnesiowuestite-bearing ULVZs (Dobrosavljevic et al. 2023, under review).
